scenes.voice_over: Combine onion, garlic, ginger, green chilies, and tomatoes in a food processor and pulse until coarsely ground. This paste will be the flavor base of our Keema Matar.

scenes.image_prompt: Cumin seeds sizzling in hot oil in a pan. Zoom out slightly to show the ground onion mixture being added to the pan.
scenes.voice_over: Heat oil in a pan over medium heat. Add cumin seeds and let them sizzle for about 30 seconds. Add the onion mixture and cook for 5-7 minutes until lightly browned.

scenes.image_prompt: Ground lamb browning in the pan with the sautéed onion mixture and spices.
scenes.voice_over: Stir in the turmeric and cook for a minute. Now, add the ground lamb and break it up with a spatula. Cook until it's nicely browned.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of spices being added to the lamb mixture: coriander powder, salt, chicken seasoning.
scenes.voice_over: Add coriander powder, salt, and chicken seasoning. Stir and cook for another 5 minutes, letting those flavors meld.

scenes.image_prompt: The pan is covered, simmering on low heat, showing the keema matar cooking.
scenes.voice_over: Add 1 cup of water, bring to a simmer, reduce heat to medium-low, cover, and cook for 15-20 minutes until the lamb is cooked through.  If using a pressure cooker, add 1/2 cup water and cook for 5-7 minutes after pressure builds.

scenes.image_prompt: Keema Matar cooking uncovered, the liquid is evaporating and the oil begins to separate from the lamb.
scenes.voice_over: Increase heat and let the liquid reduce until the oil separates from the lamb. This intensifies the flavor. Stir in the peas and cook for the final 3 minutes.

scenes.image_prompt: A close-up shot of the finished Keema Matar served hot with naan bread, garnished with fresh cilantro, with a side of rice.
scenes.voice_over: Your Keema Matar is ready! Serve it hot with naan, roti, chapatis, or rice. Enjoy this hearty and aromatic meal.  It has approximately 400 calories, 30g of protein, 25g of carbs, and 20g of fat per serving.

cooking_tips: For a richer flavor, use bone-in lamb and mince it yourself.
Adjust the amount of green chilies to control the spiciness.
If you don't have chicken seasoning, you can use garam masala instead.
Fresh or frozen peas can be used in this recipe.

recipes.name: Chicken in Cardamom Coconut Sauce
ingredients: 1/2 cup Red onion, thinly sliced half-moons (or white onion)
directions: Step 1: In a bowl, combine the crushed cardamom pods and coconut milk. Set aside.

Step 2: Season the chicken drumsticks with salt and pepper. Heat 2 tablespoons of canola oil in a deep saucepan over medium-high heat. Fry the drumsticks until light brown on all sides. Remove from the pan and set aside.
Step 3: In the same pan, add 1 tablespoon of canola oil. Fry the sliced onions, sugar, and garam masala until the onions are lightly caramelized.
Step 4: Add the red pepper powder and turmeric, and fry for 30 seconds. Return the chicken to the pan and cook for 5 minutes. Add a little water if the mixture sticks to the bottom of the pan.
Step 5: Add the tomato sauce (mixed with 1 cup of water), salt, ginger paste, and garlic paste. Cook over low heat until the oil separates from the sauce.
Step 6: Add the coconut milk mixture, cover, and cook over low heat until the chicken is fully cooked.
Step 7: Garnish with fresh chopped cilantro and serve hot with naan or chapati.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a close-up, slightly overhead shot of Chicken in Cardamom Coconut Sauce, nestled in a shallow, dark grey bowl against a textured linen backdrop in earthy tones.  Focus on the glistening sauce clinging to the chicken, highlighting its texture.  Use soft, diffused natural light to create a warm, inviting mood.  Garnish with fresh cilantro sprigs and a sprinkle of cardamom pods.  Shallow depth of field, focusing on the chicken in the foreground, with the red onion slices gently blurred in the background.

recipes.name: Kashmiri Lamb Rogan Josh
ingredients: 2 medium potatoes, cut into 1-1.5 inch cubes
2 tsp Kashmiri chili powder (or 1/2 tsp cayenne pepper + 1 tsp paprika mixed with 2 tbsp water)
1/2 cup finely chopped red onion or shallot
1.5 tbsp ginger-garlic paste (4 cloves garlic + 1 inch ginger, grated)
directions: Step 1: Heat the canola oil in a wide, heavy-bottomed skillet or pot over medium heat. Add the chopped red onion or shallot and sauté until golden brown, about 8-10 minutes.

Step 2: While the onions are cooking, prepare the chili paste by mixing the Kashmiri chili powder (or cayenne pepper and paprika) with 2 tablespoons of water. If using whole spices, gather them together for easy addition later.

Step 3: Once the onions are browned, add the whole spices (cloves, bay leaves, cardamom pods, fennel seeds, dried red chili pepper, and mace), ginger-garlic paste, chili paste, coriander powder, and turmeric powder. Sauté for 1 minute, stirring constantly.
Step 4: Add the cubed lamb to the pot and sauté for 2-3 minutes, or until the pink color of the lamb is gone.
Step 5: Transfer the lamb and spice mixture to a pressure cooker. Add the diced potatoes, 2.5 cups of water, and salt. Close the lid securely.
Step 6: Pressure cook on high for 15 minutes, or until the lamb is tender to your liking. Allow the pressure to release naturally.
Step 7: Once the pressure is released, open the cooker carefully. Stir in the plain yogurt.  If intact, remove and discard the whole spices.
Step 8: Garnish with fresh chopped cilantro leaves and serve hot with rice or traditional Indian naan bread.

Use a slightly overhead, angled shot highlighting the deep red sauce and texture of the lamb.  Shallow depth of field, focusing on a succulent piece of lamb, with soft lighting to create a warm, inviting mood. Incorporate a sprinkle of fresh cilantro and a side of naan bread as props, against a dark, textured background. Emphasize the glistening oil and steam rising gently from the dish.

If you don't have a pressure cooker, you can simmer the lamb in a covered pot on the stovetop for about 1-1.5 hours, or until tender.

recipes.name: Masala Matar (Green Pea Curry)
ingredients: 2 medium tomatoes, finely grated (or 1/4 cup tomato paste)
directions: Step 1: Prepare the Ingredients: If using fresh peas, boil them until slightly tender. If using frozen peas, no pre-cooking is needed.  Grate the tomatoes or use tomato paste.  Roughly chop the onion and garlic. Finely chop the green chilies.
Step 2: Sauté Aromatics: Heat the canola oil in a pan over medium heat. Add the cumin seeds and curry leaf. Fry for about 1 minute until fragrant.
Step 3: Sauté Onion Mixture: Add the chopped onion, garlic, and green chilies to the pan. Fry for 5-7 minutes, or until the onions are softened and lightly browned.

Step 4: Add Spices: Add the turmeric powder and coriander powder to the pan. Fry for 1 minute, stirring constantly. Add the grated tomatoes (or tomato paste) and salt. Fry for another 2-3 minutes, or until the oil starts to separate from the mixture.

Step 5: Add Yogurt and Peas: Remove the pan from the heat and let it cool slightly. Whisk the yogurt with water until smooth. Add the yogurt mixture to the pan and stir well. Return the pan to low heat. Add the green peas and 1/2 cup of water. Simmer for 5-6 minutes, or until the peas are cooked through and the sauce has thickened.
Step 6: Finish and Serve: Stir in the garam masala. Garnish with chopped cilantro. Serve hot with naan, roti, or rice.

video_script.title: Masala Matar: Easy Green Pea Curry

scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need: green peas, tomatoes, onion, garlic, green chilies, canola oil, cumin seeds, a curry leaf, coriander powder, turmeric powder, garam masala, plain yogurt, water, salt, and fresh cilantro for garnish.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of chopping onions, garlic, and green chilies.
scenes.voice_over: First, let's prep our ingredients. If using fresh peas, boil them until slightly tender.  If frozen, no pre-cooking is needed. Finely chop the onions, garlic, and green chilies. Grate the tomatoes or use tomato paste.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up of a pan with oil, cumin seeds, and curry leaf sputtering.
scenes.voice_over: Heat two tablespoons of canola oil in a pan over medium heat. Add the cumin seeds and curry leaf. Fry for about a minute until fragrant.

scenes.image_prompt: The pan with onions, garlic, and green chilies being sautéed.
scenes.voice_over: Add the chopped onions, garlic, and green chilies to the pan. Sauté for 5-7 minutes until softened and lightly browned.

scenes.image_prompt: Spices being added to the pan with the onion mixture.
scenes.voice_over: Add the turmeric powder and coriander powder. Fry for 1 minute, stirring constantly.  Then, add the grated tomatoes or tomato paste and salt. Fry for 2-3 minutes until the oil starts to separate.

scenes.image_prompt: Yogurt being whisked in a bowl and then added to the pan.
scenes.voice_over: Take the pan off the heat and let it cool slightly. Whisk the yogurt with a quarter cup of water until smooth. Add this to the pan and stir well. Return the pan to low heat, add the peas and another 1/2 cup water, and simmer for 5-6 minutes until the peas are cooked and the sauce thickens.

scenes.image_prompt: Garam masala being added to the pan and the curry being stirred.
scenes.voice_over: Stir in the garam masala. This adds a beautiful aroma and depth of flavor.

scenes.voice_over: Garnish with fresh cilantro and serve hot with naan, roti, or rice. Enjoy your delicious homemade Masala Matar!  This recipe serves two and has roughly 250 calories, 10g of protein, 40g of carbs, and 8g of fat per serving.

cooking_tips: For a richer flavor, use fresh green peas.
Adjust the amount of green chilies to control the spiciness level.
If the sauce becomes too thick, add a little more water to adjust the consistency.
